title: Judith Ivey
text:
Judith Lee Ivey (born September 4, 1951) is an American actress and theatre director. She twice won the <a href="Tony%20Award%20for%20Best%20Featured%20Actress%20in%20a%20Play">Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Play</a> for her performances in "<a href="Steaming%20%28play%29">Steaming</a>" (1981) and "<a href="Hurlyburly">Hurlyburly</a>" (1984). Ivey also appeared in several films and television series. For her role in "<a href="What%20the%20Deaf%20Man%20Heard">What the Deaf Man Heard</a>" (1997), she was nominated for a <a href="Primetime%20Emmy%20Award%20for%20Outstanding%20Supporting%20Actress%20in%20a%20Limited%20Series%20or%20Movie">Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Limited Series or Movie</a>.
Early life.
Ivey was born in <a href="El%20Paso%2C%20Texas">El Paso, Texas</a>, the daughter of Nathan Aldean Ivey, a college instructor and dean and Dorothy Lee (<a href="married%20and%20maiden%20names">née</a> Lewis), a teacher. 
She spent 1965–68 in <a href="Dowagiac%2C%20Michigan">Dowagiac, Michigan</a>, where she attended Union High School through tenth grade. She graduated from Marion High School in <a href="Marion%2C%20Illinois">Marion, Illinois</a>, in 1970, and is an alumna of <a href="John%20A.%20Logan%20College">John A. Logan College</a>, <a href="Southern%20Illinois%20University">Southern Illinois University</a> (Carbondale), and <a href="Illinois%20State%20University">Illinois State University</a> (<a href="Normal%2C%20Illinois">Normal, Illinois</a>).
Career.
Ivey won two <a href="Tony%20Awards">Tony Awards</a> as Best Featured Actress in a Play for "<a href="Steaming%20%28play%29">Steaming</a>" in 1983 and "<a href="Hurlyburly">Hurlyburly</a>" in 1985. She was also nominated for "<a href="Park%20Your%20Car%20in%20Harvard%20Yard">Park Your Car in Harvard Yard</a>" in 1992 and a revival of "<a href="The%20Heiress">The Heiress</a>" in 2013. Other Broadway theatre credits include "<a href="Piaf%20%28play%29">Piaf</a>", "<a href="Bedroom%20Farce%20%28play%29">Bedroom Farce</a>", "<a href="Blithe%20Spirit%20%28play%29">Blithe Spirit</a>", Voices in the Dark, and "<a href="Follies">Follies</a>".
She portrayed Amanda in "<a href="The%20Glass%20Menagerie">The Glass Menagerie</a>" at the <a href="Long%20Wharf%20Theatre">Long Wharf Theatre</a> and reprised the role in March 2010 at the <a href="Roundabout%20Theatre">Roundabout Theatre</a> in New York, as well as the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. She received the <a href="Lucille%20Lortel">Lucille Lortel</a> Award for Best Actress for that portrayal. Ivey portrayed <a href="Ann%20Landers">Ann Landers</a> in the solo play "The Lady With All the Answers" at the Cherry Lane Theatre (<a href="off-Broadway">off-Broadway</a>) in October 2009. She was nominated for Best Solo Performance for the Lucille Lortel Award and <a href="Drama%20Desk%20Award">Drama Desk Award</a>. In 2016, she returned to the <a href="Cherry%20Lane%20Theatre">Cherry Lane Theatre</a> in <a href="Israel%20Horovitz">Israel Horovitz</a>'s play "<a href="Out%20Of%20The%20Mouths%20Of%20Babes">Out Of The Mouths Of Babes</a>" with <a href="Estelle%20Parsons">Estelle Parsons</a>, directed by <a href="Barnet%20Kellman">Barnet Kellman</a>.
Ivey has appeared in numerous films, including "<a href="Brighton%20Beach%20Memoirs%20%28film%29">Brighton Beach Memoirs</a>", "<a href="Miles%20from%20Home">Miles from Home</a>", "<a href="Compromising%20Positions">Compromising Positions</a>", "<a href="Harry%20%26amp%3B%20Son">Harry & Son</a>", "<a href="The%20Woman%20in%20Red%20%281984%20film%29">The Woman in Red</a>", "<a href="Sister%2C%20Sister%20%281987%20film%29">Sister, Sister</a>", "<a href="In%20Country">In Country</a>", "<a href="Hello%20Again%20%281987%20film%29">Hello Again</a>", "<a href="The%20Lonely%20Guy">The Lonely Guy</a>", "<a href="There%20Goes%20the%20Neighborhood%20%28film%29">There Goes the Neighborhood</a>", "<a href="The%20Devil%27s%20Advocate%20%281997%20film%29">The Devil's Advocate</a>", "<a href="What%20Alice%20Found">What Alice Found</a>", and "<a href="Flags%20of%20Our%20Fathers">Flags of Our Fathers</a>". 
Despite a long history of theater and film performances, Ivey is often associated with the role of B.J. Poteet in the final season of "<a href="Designing%20Women">Designing Women</a>". She appeared on "<a href="Will%20%26amp%3B%20Grace">Will & Grace</a>" as the mother of <a href="Leo%20Markus">Dr. Leo Markus</a>, and also appeared on "<a href="Grey%27s%20Anatomy">Grey's Anatomy</a>", "<a href="Person%20of%20Interest%20%28TV%20series%29">Person of Interest</a>", "<a href="White%20Collar%20%28TV%20series%29">White Collar</a>", "<a href="Nurse%20Jackie">Nurse Jackie</a>", "<a href="Big%20Love">Big Love</a>", and "". 
Other television roles include starring roles as Kate McCrorey in the 1990–91 series "<a href="Down%20Home%20%28TV%20series%29">Down Home</a>", set in a Texas coastal town, Alexandra Buchanan in the short-lived series "<a href="The%205%20Mrs.%20Buchanans">The 5 Mrs. Buchanans</a>", and "Buddies" with Dave Chappelle. Ivey was also in the 1985 TV remake of "<a href="The%20Long%20Hot%20Summer">The Long Hot Summer</a>", in the role of Noel Varner (<a href="Joanne%20Woodward">Joanne Woodward</a>'s role in the 1958 film version). The miniseries also starred <a href="Jason%20Robards">Jason Robards</a> and <a href="Don%20Johnson">Don Johnson</a>. Ivey was nominated for an Emmy for her performance in "What the Deaf Man Heard", a Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation. She also provided the voice of <a href="The%20Critic%23Eleanor%20Sherman%20%28n%C3%A9e%20Wigglesworth%29">Eleanor Sherman</a> in the <a href="animated%20series">animated series</a> "<a href="The%20Critic">The Critic</a>". Ivey appeared in the television miniseries "<a href="Rose%20Red%20%28miniseries%29">Rose Red</a>" (based on a <a href="Stephen%20King">Stephen King</a> novel) as Cathy, one of the psychics investigating a haunted house.
Personal life.
Ivey was married to actor <a href="Ricardo%20Gutierrez">Ricardo Gutierrez</a>. They divorced before her move to New York. She is now married to Tim Braine and they have two children. Ivey has a sister and a brother, Sara and James, respectively. Sara is a writer/producer/director who lives in Dallas, Texas, and James is a former professor of theater at the State University of New York at Fredonia.
